title: The controversial origins of the Encyclopedia - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Why was Denis Diderot locked up under royal order in 1749?

options.label: A
options.text: For writing a poem about the beauty of nature

options.label: B
options.text: For translating a book without permission

options.label: C
options.text: For an essay about a philosopher's deathbed rejection of God

options.label: D
options.text: For writing a novel about the French monarchy

multiple-choice.question: Who hired Denis Diderot to adapt the English cyclopedia for French subscribers in 1745?
How many entries and words did the first encyclopedia contain?
Who wrote the famous preliminary discourse in the encyclopedia?
How many articles did Louis de Jaucourt write for the encyclopedia?
Why did Pope Clement XIII order the encyclopedia to be burned?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was written in French

multiple-choice.question: Who helped Diderot by tipping him off to impending raids and hiding his papers?
What happened to the uncensored pages of the encyclopedia that were secretly edited by the publisher?

options.label: B
options.text: They were published in a later edition

options.label: D
options.text: They were burned by the Pope

multiple-choice.question: What is considered a cornerstone of the Enlightenment and a testament to France's crisis of authority?
What is unique about Diderot's entry on the plant aguaxima?

options.label: D
options.text: It is not included in the encyclopedia

title: The science of skin color - Angela Koine Flynn

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary factor that determines how quickly a person's skin changes color when exposed to ultraviolet sunlight?
What is the name of the pigment responsible for giving skin and hair its color?
Which type of melanin is responsible for producing brown skin tones, as well as black, brown, and blond hair?
Approximately how many years ago did humans begin to migrate north from Africa and into Europe and Asia, leading to the formation of varying skin tones?
What is the name of the deadly cancer that can form in the skin's melanocytes as a result of severe DNA damage from UV light?
How did our ancestors cope with the onslaught of UV light before the existence of sunscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: They used clothing to cover their skin

options.label: B
options.text: They stayed indoors during the day

options.label: C
options.text: They manufactured their own personal sunscreen beneath the skin, melanin

options.label: D
options.text: They used umbrellas to block the sun

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the special light-sensitive receptors that stimulate the production of melanin to shield cells from damage?
What is the benefit of UV light that is essential for human health, aside from causing damage to the skin?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps our bodies produce vitamin C

options.label: B
options.text: It helps our bodies produce vitamin D

options.label: C
options.text: It helps our bodies produce melanin

options.label: D
options.text: It helps our bodies produce rhodopsin

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition that can result from a vitamin D deficiency, causing serious fatigue and weakened bones?
Why do people living near the Equator typically have darker skin, while those living in regions with less sunlight have lighter skin?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The tone or pitch of one's voice

title: Every kid needs a champion - Rita Pierson

multiple-choice.question: According to James Comer, what is necessary for significant learning to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: He became upset and argued with the teacher

options.label: B
options.text: He asked if it was an F and then understood the teacher's encouragement

options.label: D
options.text: He refused to take any more quizzes

options.label: A
options.text: She focused solely on academics and ignored their personal needs

options.label: B
options.text: She took the time to review material with them, made home visits, and provided basic necessities

options.label: C

options.text: She did not get involved in their personal lives

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: She reported her colleague to the administration

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker give to her students to help raise their self-esteem and academic achievement?

options.label: A
options.text: A list of rules and expectations

options.label: B
options.text: A saying to repeat: "I am somebody. I was somebody when I came. I'll be a better somebody when I leave."

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: Because of the connection and relationships with the teacher

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A champion who will never give up on them

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Because they wanted to show respect for her as a teacher

options.label: C
options.text: Because she had made a lasting impact on their lives and they wanted to pay their respects

options.label: D

options.label: B

title: The immortal cells of Henrietta Lacks - Robin Bulleri

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of growing human cells in a lab?

options.label: B
options.text: To study how cells function, understand how diseases develop, and test new treatments

multiple-choice.question: Why did human cell lines grown in labs typically die after a few days before 1951?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to a lack of nutrients

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were not identical cells

options.label: C
options.text: They had built-in control mechanisms that limited their division

multiple-choice.question: What made the cells from Henrietta Lacks' tumor special?

options.label: A
options.text: They were able to divide indefinitely

options.label: B
options.text: They had a limited number of cell divisions

options.label: C
options.text: They were only able to divide 50 times

options.label: D
options.text: They were not able to divide at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the scientist who first received the sample of Henrietta Lacks' tumor?
What is the term for the process by which normal human cells self-destruct after a certain number of divisions?
What was the result of Dr. Gey realizing he had the first immortal line of human cells?

options.label: B
options.text: He sent samples to labs all over the world

options.label: D
options.text: He sold the cells for profit

multiple-choice.question: What significant discovery was made possible by HeLa cells in the fight against polio?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of a cure for polio

options.label: B
options.text: The creation of a vaccine for polio

options.label: C
options.text: The understanding of the causes of polio

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the chromosomes in HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: They have the typical 46 human chromosomes

options.label: B
options.text: They have around 80 highly mutated chromosomes

multiple-choice.question: What enzyme was discovered first in HeLa cells that helps cancer cells evade destruction?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is caused by a genetic mutation

options.label: B
options.text: That it is caused by a virus called HPV

title: #TEDEdChat: A Math Class Makeover | Dan Meyer |

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's profession?
According to the speaker, what is the main issue with math education in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: Students are not learning enough formulas

options.label: B
options.text: Students are not retaining math reasoning skills

options.label: C
options.text: Students are not interested in math

options.label: D
options.text: Teachers are not qualified to teach math

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between computation and math reasoning, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Computation is easier to learn, while math reasoning is harder

options.label: B
options.text: Computation involves applying formulas, while math reasoning involves applying math to real-world problems

options.label: C
options.text: Computation is only used in math class, while math reasoning is used in all subjects

options.label: D
options.text: Computation is more important than math reasoning

multiple-choice.question: What is one symptom that you're doing math reasoning wrong in your classroom, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Students are too eager to solve word problems

options.label: C
options.text: Students are too focused on learning formulas

options.label: D
options.text: Students are not interested in math

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with the way textbooks teach math reasoning, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide too many word problems

options.label: C
options.text: They present problems in a way that is too straightforward and doesn't require critical thinking

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker suggest teaching math reasoning?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing more formulas and procedures

options.label: B
options.text: By presenting problems in a more straightforward way

options.label: C
options.text: By encouraging students to develop their own problem-solving strategies

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using multimedia in the classroom, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the lesson more boring

options.label: B
options.text: It provides more formulas and procedures

options.label: C
options.text: It brings the real world into the classroom in high resolution and full color

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think it's an amazing time to be a math teacher?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there are more textbooks available

options.label: B
options.text: Because there are more formulas to teach

options.label: C
options.text: Because we have the tools to create high-quality curriculum and distribute it freely

options.label: D
options.text: Because students are more interested in math

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal for his students?

options.label: B
options.text: To become more patient problem solvers

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think math is important?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is required by law

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a vocabulary for your own intuition

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is only used in math class

title: Why certain wildfires are necessary - Jim Schulz

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary source of fire for early hominids, according to anthropologists?

options.label: B
options.text: It allowed them to cook food and clear land

options.label: C
options.text: It helped them to build shelters

options.label: D
options.text: It enabled them to hunt more effectively

options.label: A
options.text: Due to a lack of water

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the cool, sunless shade created by their towering parents

options.label: C
options.text: As a result of soil erosion

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.text: To reduce fuels and prevent more destructive wildfires

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a fire-dependent forest going too long without burning?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: The forest is less susceptible to disease

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Can you solve the temple riddle? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: What event triggers the walls of the ancient temple to start shaking?

options.label: A
options.text: The expedition leader studies the inscriptions in the near total darkness.

options.label: B
options.text: Two graduate students bump into the altar.

options.label: C
options.text: The expedition team discovers the hidden switches.

options.label: D
options.text: The team evades the secret traps.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of the giant sandglass in the center of the room emptying?

options.label: A
options.text: The temple will fill with green smoke.

multiple-choice.question: How many people, including the expedition leader, are in the group?
What is the problem with the two students who bumped into the altar?

options.label: C
options.text: They are possessed by the spirits of the city's King and Queen.

multiple-choice.question: How does the curse affect the possessed students?

options.label: C
options.text: They may lie or tell the truth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the strategy for exploring the four halls ahead?

options.label: A
options.text: Send groups of four down each path.

options.label: B
options.text: Send one person down each path.

options.label: C
options.text: Send the expedition leader down one path and split the remaining students into one pair and two trios.

options.label: D
options.text: Send all students down one path.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it reliable to trust a trio that returns in total agreement?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the expedition leader is with them.

options.label: B
options.text: Because there are only two possessed students, and the other six will always tell the truth.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are the first group to return.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are the last group to return.

multiple-choice.question: What happens if each group gives a consistent answer?

options.label: A
options.text: The expedition leader knows which path to take.

options.label: B
options.text: The two possessed students are paired together, or everyone is telling the truth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome if there are two conflicts among the groups?

options.label: A
options.text: The expedition leader must guess which path to take.

options.label: B
options.text: The possessed students are in separate groups, and the majority in both trios can be trusted.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the two possessed students after the ordeal?

options.label: A
options.text: They are trapped in the temple.

options.label: B
options.text: They are freed from the curse.

options.text: Read science fiction novels for inspiration

options.label: C

title: Why are human bodies asymmetrical? - Leo Q. Wan

multiple-choice.question: What is a common feature of some snail species' shells?

options.label: B
options.text: They always coil in the same direction.

options.label: C
options.text: They change color depending on the environment.

options.label: D
options.text: They are made of a hard, impermeable material.

multiple-choice.question: How are most of the vital organs in the human body arranged?

options.label: A
options.text: Symmetrically, with each side mirroring the other.

options.label: C
options.text: Asymmetrically, with most organs on the left side.

options.label: D
options.text: Asymmetrically, with most organs on the right side.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the condition where all internal organs are flipped?
What is the theory behind the development of asymmetry in embryos?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by external environmental factors.

options.label: B
options.text: It is due to the presence of a small pit called a node with tiny hairs called cilia.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a result of genetic mutations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the cilia on the node of an embryo?

options.label: A
options.text: To sense fluid flow and activate specific genes.

options.label: B
options.text: To push fluid from the left side of the embryo to the right.

options.label: C
options.text: To rotate rapidly and create a whirlpool effect.

options.label: D
options.text: To tilt away from the head and create a current.

multiple-choice.question: In which organ does asymmetry first appear during embryonic development?
What is the property of biomolecules that contributes to asymmetry at the molecular level?
What is an example of an organism that does not have embryonic cilia but still has asymmetric internal organs?
How do human cells cultured inside a ring-shaped boundary tend to arrange themselves?

options.label: D
options.text: Like the ridges on a cruller.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of proteins that control cell migration and embryonic cilia twirl?

options.label: C
options.text: They are made up of only one type of amino acid.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only found in certain types of cells.

title: When will the next mass extinction occur? - Borths, D'Emic, and Pritchard

multiple-choice.question: What event occurred around 66 million years ago that significantly impacted life on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive earthquake struck the planet.

options.label: B
options.text: Massive volcanic eruptions filled the atmosphere with carbon dioxide and an asteroid hit the Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: A giant tsunami swept across the globe.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the dust from the asteroid impact on plant life?

options.label: A
options.text: It increased photosynthesis in many plants.

options.label: B
options.text: It had no effect on plant life.

options.label: C
options.text: It reduced or stopped photosynthesis in many plants.

options.label: D
options.text: It caused plants to grow at an alarming rate.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the world's species disappeared during the mass extinction event 66 million years ago?
What is the term used to describe the sudden disappearance of thousands of species due to massive changes in the environment?
What was the largest mass extinction event in Earth's history, and when did it occur?

options.label: A
options.text: The extinction of the dinosaurs, 66 million years ago

options.label: B
options.text: The Permian-Triassic extinction, 252 million years ago

options.label: C
options.text: The Ice Age extinction, 10,000 years ago

options.label: D
options.text: The Cambrian explosion, 541 million years ago

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the massive volcanic eruptions in Siberia during the Permian-Triassic extinction?
What was the impact of the fluctuation of massive ice sheets on sea levels and weather patterns?

options.label: A
options.text: It caused sea levels to remain constant and weather patterns to stay the same.

options.label: B
options.text: It caused sea levels to rise and fall, changing weather patterns and ocean currents.

options.label: C
options.text: It only affected the polar regions.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on sea levels or weather patterns.

multiple-choice.question: What is believed to have contributed to the extinction of large mammals such as giant ground sloths and mammoths?

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of climate change and human activity

options.label: D
options.text: Neither climate change nor human activity

multiple-choice.question: How do current rates of extinction compare to the normal background rate?

options.label: A
options.text: They are similar to the normal background rate.

options.label: B
options.text: They are slightly higher than the normal background rate.

options.label: C
options.text: They are hundreds to thousands of times higher than the normal background rate.

options.label: D
options.text: They are lower than the normal background rate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome if humans use their knowledge to lessen their impact on other species?

options.label: A
options.text: Humans will inevitably drive all other species to extinction.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans will have no impact on the environment.

options.label: C
options.text: Humans can transform their impact on the world from destructive to collaborative.

options.label: D
options.text: Humans will only be able to slow down the rate of extinction.

title: Holocaust survivor Francine Christophe shares her story

options.label: A
options.text: To create a visually appealing product

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a solution that meets user needs

multiple-choice.question: Which design principle emphasizes the use of simple and intuitive interfaces?
